title: OSINT Tools Overview
description: Explore a variety of tools designed specifically for OSINT investigations and learn when to use each one.

sections.content:
Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) relies heavily on specialized tools that help investigators collect, analyze, and visualize information from publicly available sources. Understanding which tools to use for specific tasks is essential for conducting efficient and effective investigations.

This module provides a comprehensive overview of the most valuable OSINT tools across different categories, explaining their capabilities, use cases, and how they fit into a complete OSINT workflow. You'll learn about both free and commercial options, with an emphasis on tools that are accessible to beginners while still being powerful enough for professional use.

By the end of this module, you'll be able to:

  • Identify the right tools for specific OSINT tasks
  • Understand the strengths and limitations of different tools
  • Build a personalized OSINT toolkit based on your needs
  • Integrate multiple tools into a cohesive workflow
  • Access resources for learning more about specialized tools

Let's explore the essential tools that will form the foundation of your OSINT investigations.

sections.title: Building Your OSINT Toolkit
sections.content:
Before diving into specific tools, it's important to understand how to approach building your OSINT toolkit.

Key Principles

  • Purpose-Driven Selection: Choose tools based on your specific investigation needs
  • Redundancy: Have multiple tools that can accomplish similar tasks
  • Security Awareness: Consider the security implications of each tool
  • Learning Curve: Balance capability with ease of use
  • Integration: Consider how tools work together in your workflow

Core Categories

A well-rounded OSINT toolkit should include tools from these essential categories:

  • Search and Discovery: Tools for finding information across the web
  • Social Media Analysis: Tools for investigating social platforms
  • People Search: Tools for finding information about individuals
  • Website Analysis: Tools for examining websites and domains
  • Geolocation: Tools for location-based investigations
  • Image Analysis: Tools for examining and verifying images
  • Data Organization: Tools for managing your findings

Start with a small set of versatile tools and expand as you gain experience and encounter more specialized needs. It's better to be proficient with a few tools than to be overwhelmed by many.

sections.title: Search and Discovery Tools
sections.content:
Search tools form the foundation of any OSINT investigation, allowing you to discover information across the web.

General Search Engines

  • Google: The most powerful search engine when used with advanced operators
  • Bing: Microsoft's search engine, sometimes indexes content Google misses
  • DuckDuckGo: Privacy-focused search engine that doesn't track users
  • Yandex: Russian search engine with strong image search capabilities
  • Baidu: Chinese search engine useful for investigations in Asia

Specialized Search Tools

  • Google Dorking: Using advanced Google search operators for precise queries
  • Shodan: Search engine for internet-connected devices
  • Archive.org (Wayback Machine): Access to archived versions of websites
  • Google Dataset Search: Search engine for datasets
  • Google Scholar: Search engine for academic papers

Meta-Search Tools

  • Searx: Privacy-focused metasearch engine
  • StartPage: Google search results with enhanced privacy
  • Carrot2: Search results clustering engine

When investigating a company, an effective approach is to use multiple search engines with specific operators. For example, searching site:example.com filetype:pdf on both Google and Bing might reveal different documents, giving you a more complete picture.

sections.title: Search Tool Comparison Exercise
sections.content:
In this exercise, you'll compare the results from different search engines to understand their strengths and weaknesses.

Instructions

  1. Choose a specific search query related to a topic of interest (e.g., a company name, technology, or event)
  2. Run the exact same query on Google, Bing, DuckDuckGo, and Yandex
  3. Compare the first page of results from each search engine
  4. Note any unique results that appear in only one search engine
  5. Try adding an advanced operator (like filetype:pdf or site:.gov) to your query and repeat the comparison

Questions to Consider

  • Which search engine provided the most relevant results for your query?
  • Did any search engines find unique information that others missed?
  • How did the results change when you added advanced operators?
  • Based on this exercise, which search engines would you prioritize for different types of investigations?

Document your findings in a simple table or spreadsheet to help you remember which search engines excel at different types of queries.
sections.solution:
Sample Comparison Results

For the query "cybersecurity trends" filetype:pdf site:.gov:

Excellent handling of advanced operators		Some results were personalized despite using incognito mode
BingFound older archived PDFs from NISTBetter historical coverage
Some unique military domain results		Fewer total relevant results
Less precise with the filetype operator

Clean interface		Significantly fewer relevant results
Less effective with complex operators

Key Takeaways

  • Google remains the most comprehensive option for most searches, especially with advanced operators
  • Bing sometimes indexes older content that Google has removed
  • DuckDuckGo offers privacy benefits but with less comprehensive results
  • Yandex provides valuable alternative perspectives, especially for international topics
  • Using multiple search engines provides the most complete picture

sections.title: Social Media Investigation Tools
sections.content:
Social media platforms contain vast amounts of valuable information for OSINT investigations. These tools help you discover, analyze, and archive social media content.

Cross-Platform Tools

  • Social Searcher: Search across multiple social platforms without logging in
  • Hootsuite: Monitor multiple social networks from one dashboard
  • Mention: Track mentions across social media and the web
  • Brand24: Social media monitoring and analytics tool

Twitter/X Tools

  • TweetDeck: Advanced Twitter dashboard for monitoring multiple feeds
  • Twint: Twitter scraping tool that doesn't use Twitter's API
  • Twitonomy: Detailed Twitter analytics and insights
  • Foller.me: Twitter analytics focused on account behavior

Instagram Tools

  • Instaloader: Download Instagram profiles, hashtags, and locations
  • ImgInn: View Instagram profiles without an account
  • Picuki: Instagram editor and viewer

Facebook Tools

  • Who Posted What: Search Facebook posts by date range and keywords
  • StalkScan: Find information that might be hidden but publicly available

LinkedIn Tools

  • LinkedIn Sales Navigator: Advanced search capabilities (paid)
  • Recruiter Lite: Find and track profiles (paid)

Archiving Tools

  • Hunchly: Automatically capture and organize web pages during investigations
  • Archive.today: Save snapshots of web pages, including social media
  • Wayback Machine: Archive and access historical versions of websites

Always respect platform terms of service when using these tools. Many platforms have restrictions on automated data collection, and violating these terms can result in account suspension or legal issues.

sections.title: People Search and Background Check Tools
sections.content:
These tools help you find information about individuals, including contact details, social profiles, and background information.

General People Search

  • Pipl: Comprehensive people search engine (paid)
  • Spokeo: People search engine with contact info and social profiles
  • That's Them: Free people and business search
  • Hunter.io: Find email addresses by domain name
  • Clearbit Connect: Find email addresses and company information

Public Records

  • BeenVerified: Background check service (paid)
  • TruthFinder: Public records search (paid)
  • PACER: Public Access to Court Electronic Records (US)
  • SearchSystems: Directory of free public records

Username and Identity

  • Namechk: Check username availability across multiple platforms
  • WhatsMyName: Find usernames across many platforms
  • Sherlock: Command-line tool to find usernames across social networks
  • GHunt: Investigate Google accounts with an email

Professional and Academic

  • LinkedIn: Professional networking and information
  • Google Scholar: Academic papers and citations
  • ORCID: Open Researcher and Contributor ID database

Many people search tools require payment for full results. Always consider the ethical and legal implications of conducting background checks on individuals, and ensure you have a legitimate purpose that complies with relevant privacy laws.

sections.title: Website and Domain Analysis Tools
sections.content:
These tools help you investigate websites, domains, and their ownership, history, and technical details.

WHOIS and Domain Tools

  • ICANN WHOIS: Official WHOIS lookup for domain registration information
  • DomainTools: Comprehensive domain intelligence (paid)
  • ViewDNS.info: Multiple DNS and domain lookup tools
  • Whoxy: WHOIS search with historical data (paid)

Website Analysis

  • BuiltWith: Discover what technologies websites are using
  • Wappalyzer: Browser extension that identifies web technologies
  • SpyOnWeb: Find websites sharing the same tracking codes
  • Similar Web: Website traffic and analytics

Historical Analysis

  • Wayback Machine: View archived versions of websites
  • Archive.today: Another web archiving service
  • Cached View: View Google's cached version of pages

Security and Infrastructure

  • Shodan: Search engine for internet-connected devices
  • Censys: Search engine for internet devices and certificates
  • SecurityTrails: DNS, domain, and IP intelligence
  • VirusTotal: Analyze suspicious websites and files

When investigating a suspicious website, a thorough approach might include: checking WHOIS information for ownership details, examining historical versions in the Wayback Machine to see how it has changed, using BuiltWith to identify the technologies it uses, and scanning it with VirusTotal to check for malicious content.

sections.title: Website Investigation Exercise
sections.content:
In this exercise, you'll practice using website analysis tools to gather intelligence about a domain.

Instructions

  1. Choose a website to investigate (consider using a well-known company website)
  2. Use WHOIS lookup tools to find registration information
  3. Check the Wayback Machine to see how the site has evolved
  4. Use BuiltWith or Wappalyzer to identify technologies used
  5. Look up the site on SecurityTrails to find subdomains and DNS information
  6. Check Similar Web for traffic information and connected sites

Questions to Answer

  • Who owns the domain and when was it registered?
  • What significant changes has the website undergone over time?
  • What technologies does the website use?
  • What subdomains exist for this domain?
  • Where does the website's traffic come from?
  • What other domains might be connected to this one?

Document your findings in a structured report that organizes the information into clear categories.
sections.solution:
Sample Website Investigation Report

Target: example.com

Domain Registration Information
  • Registrar: Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA)
  • Registration Date: August 1, 1995
  • Expiration Date: August 13, 2023
  • Registrant Organization: Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN)
  • Registrant Country: United States
Historical Development
  • First Archived Version: October 13, 1996
  • Major Redesigns: 1999, 2004, 2015, 2020
  • Content Evolution: Originally a simple placeholder, evolved to include more detailed explanations of domain name concepts
  • Ownership Changes: Transferred to ICANN management in 1998
Technical Profile
  • Web Server: Apache
  • CMS: Custom
  • JavaScript Libraries: jQuery
  • Analytics: None detected
  • CDN: Cloudflare
  • Security: HTTPS, HSTS
Infrastructure
  • IP Address: 93.184.216.34
  • Hosting Provider: Cloudflare
  • Nameservers: a.iana-servers.net, b.iana-servers.net
  • Subdomains: www.example.com, test.example.com
  • MX Records: No mail servers configured
Traffic Analysis
  • Global Rank: ~10,000
  • Monthly Visits: ~500,000 (estimated)
  • Traffic Sources: Direct (70%), Search (25%), Referrals (5%)
  • Top Countries: United States, India, United Kingdom, Germany, Canada
  • Related Sites: example.net, example.org, iana.org
Key Findings
  • Example.com is maintained by ICANN as a demonstration domain
  • The site has remained relatively simple over its 25+ year history
  • It serves primarily as an educational resource about domain names
  • The domain receives significant traffic despite its simple content, likely due to its use in documentation and testing
  • The infrastructure is professionally maintained with modern security practices

sections.title: Geolocation and Mapping Tools
sections.content:
Geolocation tools help you identify and analyze locations in OSINT investigations, from confirming where photos were taken to mapping connections between entities.

Mapping Platforms

  • Google Maps: Comprehensive mapping with Street View and satellite imagery
  • Google Earth: 3D representation of Earth with historical imagery
  • Bing Maps: Alternative mapping platform with Bird's Eye view
  • OpenStreetMap: Open-source mapping platform with detailed data
  • Wikimapia: Crowdsourced map with annotated locations

Specialized Geolocation Tools

  • SunCalc: Calculate sun positions and phases for any location and time
  • ShadowCalculator: Analyze shadows to determine time and location
  • GeoGuessr: Practice geolocation skills with a game format
  • Mapillary: Crowdsourced street-level imagery
  • KartaView: Open-source street view platform

Geospatial Analysis

  • QGIS: Open-source Geographic Information System
  • BatchGeo: Create maps from spreadsheet data
  • Google Earth Pro: Advanced version with additional features
  • Sentinel Hub: Access to satellite imagery

Location Data Tools

  • IP Geolocation: Tools like IP2Location and MaxMind
  • What3Words: Location reference system using three words
  • ExifTool: Extract location data from image metadata

When geolocating images, look for multiple reference points rather than relying on a single landmark. Combining distinctive buildings, road layouts, vegetation patterns, and terrain features will lead to more accurate location identification.

sections.title: Image and Media Analysis Tools
sections.content:
These tools help you analyze, verify, and extract information from images, videos, and other media.

Reverse Image Search

  • Google Images: Find similar images and sources
  • TinEye: Reverse image search with historical results
  • Yandex Images: Often finds matches that Google misses
  • Bing Visual Search: Microsoft's reverse image search
  • PimEyes: Facial recognition search engine (paid)

Metadata Analysis

  • ExifTool: Extract metadata from images and files
  • Jeffrey's Image Metadata Viewer: Online EXIF data viewer
  • Forensically: Digital image forensics tool
  • FotoForensics: Error Level Analysis and metadata extraction

Video Analysis

  • InVID: Video verification plugin
  • YouTube DataViewer: Extract hidden metadata from YouTube videos
  • Frame by Frame: Analyze videos frame by frame
  • Amnesty YouTube Metadata: Extract metadata from YouTube videos

Image Enhancement

  • Let's Enhance: AI-powered image enhancement
  • GIMP: Free image editing software
  • ImageJ: Image processing program

When verifying the authenticity of an image, a thorough approach includes: checking metadata with ExifTool, running reverse image searches on multiple engines to find earlier versions, examining the image with Forensically for signs of manipulation, and analyzing shadows and lighting for consistency.

sections.title: Data Organization and Visualization Tools
sections.content:
These tools help you organize, analyze, and visualize the information you collect during OSINT investigations.

Note-Taking and Organization

  • Hunchly: Capture and organize web pages during investigations
  • Notion: All-in-one workspace for notes and databases
  • Obsidian: Knowledge base with linked notes
  • Joplin: Open-source note-taking with encryption
  • OneNote: Microsoft's note-taking application

Link Analysis and Visualization

  • Maltego: Interactive data mining and visualization
  • Gephi: Open-source network visualization software
  • NodeXL: Excel template for network analysis
  • Analyst's Notebook: IBM's visual intelligence analysis software (paid)

Timeline Tools

  • Timeline JS: Create interactive timelines
  • Aeon Timeline: Timeline visualization software (paid)
  • Tiki-Toki: Web-based timeline maker

Data Analysis

  • OpenRefine: Clean and transform data
  • Tableau Public: Data visualization platform
  • R with RStudio: Statistical computing and graphics
  • Python with Jupyter Notebooks: Data analysis and visualization

Organizing information is as important as collecting it. Without a systematic approach to data organization, valuable connections and insights can be missed. Invest time in setting up a consistent system for documenting your findings from the beginning of an investigation.

sections.title: Building Your Personal OSINT Toolkit
sections.content:
In this exercise, you'll design a personalized OSINT toolkit based on your specific needs and interests.

Instructions

  1. Identify 2-3 types of OSINT investigations you're most interested in (e.g., social media research, geolocation, corporate research)
  2. For each investigation type, select tools from different categories that would be most useful
  3. Consider both free and paid options, noting which paid tools might be worth investing in
  4. Think about how these tools would work together in your workflow
  5. Create a plan for learning and mastering these tools

Toolkit Template

For each investigation type, list:

  • Essential tools (3-5 core tools you'll use regularly)
  • Supplementary tools (additional tools for specific situations)
  • Learning resources (tutorials, documentation, courses)
  • Workflow description (how you'll use these tools together)

Create a document or spreadsheet with your toolkit plan that you can refer to and update as you gain experience.
sections.solution:
Sample OSINT Toolkit Plan

Social Media Investigation Toolkit

Essential Tools:

  • Social Searcher - For initial cross-platform searching
  • Twint - For in-depth Twitter data collection
  • Wayback Machine - For finding deleted content
  • Hunchly - For documenting findings
  • WhatsMyName - For username searches across platforms

Supplementary Tools:

  • Instaloader - For Instagram investigations
  • Who Posted What - For Facebook investigations
  • Maltego - For visualizing connections between accounts
  • TweetDeck - For monitoring ongoing activity

Learning Resources:

  • Bellingcat's Online Investigation Toolkit
  • Michael Bazzell's OSINT books and courses
  • Twint documentation on GitHub
  • Hunchly tutorial videos

Workflow:

  1. Initial cross-platform search with Social Searcher to identify relevant accounts
  2. Username search with WhatsMyName to find connected accounts
  3. In-depth data collection with platform-specific tools
  4. Historical content check with Wayback Machine
  5. Documentation of all findings with Hunchly
  6. Connection visualization with Maltego for complex cases
Geolocation Investigation Toolkit

Essential Tools:

  • Google Earth Pro - For detailed satellite imagery analysis
  • Google Maps with Street View - For ground-level perspectives
  • SunCalc - For shadow analysis
  • ExifTool - For extracting image metadata
  • Yandex Images - For reverse image search

Supplementary Tools:

  • Mapillary - For additional street-level imagery
  • Wikimapia - For crowdsourced location information
  • ShadowCalculator - For precise shadow analysis
  • QGIS - For advanced geospatial analysis

Learning Resources:

  • Bellingcat's Geolocation Guides
  • GeoGuessr to practice skills
  • QGIS tutorials
  • Google Earth Pro tutorials

Workflow:

  1. Extract location metadata with ExifTool if available
  2. Identify distinctive features in the image
  3. Use reverse image search to find potential matches
  4. Compare features using Google Earth and Street View
  5. Verify with shadow analysis using SunCalc
  6. Document findings with screenshots and coordinates
Corporate Research Toolkit

Essential Tools:

  • Google with advanced operators - For targeted searching
  • Hunter.io - For finding email addresses
  • LinkedIn - For employee information
  • DomainTools - For website ownership information
  • OpenCorporates - For company registration data

Supplementary Tools:

  • EDGAR - For SEC filings (US companies)
  • Crunchbase - For startup and funding information
  • BuiltWith - For website technology analysis
  • Similar Web - For website traffic analysis

Learning Resources:

  • SANS OSINT courses
  • Corporate research guides from investigative journalists
  • SEC filing analysis tutorials
  • Advanced Google search operator guides

Workflow:

  1. Basic company profile research with OpenCorporates and Google
  2. Website analysis with DomainTools and BuiltWith
  3. Employee research with LinkedIn and Hunter.io
  4. Financial research with EDGAR or equivalent
  5. Competitive analysis with Similar Web
  6. Documentation in structured format with cross-references

sections.title: OSINT Automation and Programming Tools
sections.content:
For more advanced OSINT work, these tools help automate tasks and create custom solutions for specific investigation needs.

OSINT Frameworks

  • Recon-ng: Web reconnaissance framework
  • SpiderFoot: Automated OSINT collection platform
  • OSINT Framework: Collection of OSINT tools and resources
  • Maltego: Visual link analysis with transforms for automation
  • theHarvester: Email, subdomain, and name harvester

Programming Languages and Libraries

  • Python: Versatile language with many OSINT libraries
  • R: Statistical computing and graphics
  • JavaScript: Web scraping and browser automation

Key Python Libraries

  • Requests: HTTP library for web requests
  • Beautiful Soup: Web scraping library
  • Selenium: Browser automation
  • Tweepy: Twitter API library
  • NLTK: Natural Language Toolkit for text analysis
  • Pandas: Data analysis library
  • NetworkX: Network analysis and visualization

Automation Platforms

  • Zapier: Connect apps and automate workflows
  • IFTTT: If This Then That automation
  • Google Apps Script: Automate tasks across Google services

Even if you're not a programmer, learning basic automation can significantly enhance your OSINT capabilities. Start with simple tools like IFTTT or Zapier before moving to programming languages like Python.

Having the right tools is essential for effective OSINT investigations, but remember that tools are only as good as the investigator using them. As you build your OSINT toolkit, focus on:

  • Mastering Core Tools: Develop deep expertise with a few essential tools rather than superficial knowledge of many
  • Understanding Capabilities and Limitations: Know what each tool can and cannot do
  • Staying Current: The OSINT landscape evolves rapidly as new tools emerge and existing ones change
  • Ethical Usage: Always use these tools responsibly and legally
  • Verification: Use multiple tools to cross-verify findings

Your OSINT toolkit will evolve as you gain experience and as new tools become available. Regularly review and update your toolkit, and don't hesitate to experiment with new tools that might enhance your capabilities.

Remember that the most powerful tool in OSINT is critical thinking. Tools can help you find and organize information, but your analytical skills will ultimately determine the success of your investigations.
